story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We are sad to share with you the loss of Sandra Veal, our mum, who will be desperately missed by us all. She was a wonderful and loving wife, mum, nan, sister, auntie and a true friend to many people.  

As some of you know she recently suffered a stroke, which we now know was caused by an underlying condition of pancreatic cancer. Dad visited her every day in hospital, but the current restrictions made such things very difficult for them both. However, a few weeks ago she was allowed to come home and dad did an incredible job of looking after her. Poor mum did not win the fight against the cancer which caused a heart attack from which she did not regain consciousness and she passed away peacefully in King’s College Hospital, on 2nd December.

Her funeral will be held at 2pm on 22nd December, however due to COVID restrictions we will not be able to host a service that will do her justice. If you would like to light a candle or join the ceremony remotely, there will be a webcast of the event at the Chapel in Beckenham. Please go to https://www.obitus.com/ to login to see the proceedings. You need to use a username: Puhu3986 along with a password of 646692. A recording will be available for a week or so, if you cannot view it at the time.

We are going to arrange all the flowers for the day, as mum loved them, but we ask that no other flowers be sent. Instead, we believe mum would prefer it if you could make a charitable donation via this link: ﻿https://justgiving.com/sandra-veal if you would like to do so. All donations will go to Macmillan Cancer Support.

We hope to arrange a memorial service for mum when COVID restrictions are lifted and will let you know further details as soon as we can. 

We all appreciate the love and support you have shown us - thank you.

story:
Over 30 years ago my Mam dragged me along to her Hi-Lo Areobic class in Newcastle with the legendary fitness presenter Helen Henderson.  Mainly in the hope for showing me up as I was in so many sports teams.  Her plan worked I looked like a clown with two left feet, but I was hooked! 

Within a year I was teach classes at Earls Court Fitness Club. Fast forward 20 years and my Mam was showing off in all my Zuma and Bootcamp sessions and Helen was guiding me into fitness presenting and competitions.

Unfortunately 4 years ago my Mam started to feel ill, yet still came to classes and did what she could.  She then became seriously ill and we found out it was stage 4 cancer. Over the following 3 years she beat it twice before it became terminal and she passed away peacefully at home surrounded by her family.  Luckily I see my Mam in my daughters eyes every time her face lights up with her infectious smile, sadly its the Grandaughter my Mam never met, but would have adored.

So in honour of Sandra Souter, one of the strongest women I will be presenting a fun fitness workout for everyone. 

Please come and help give back to the amazing Macmillan nurses who really helped my Mam and us through a tough final 10 weeks, even taking the time to attend her funeral.

I know its been a tough year for us all, give what you can no matter how little it will all help.

Thanks and looking forward to seeing you in class.

David

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I wanted to do something to raise money this year due to the problems charities are experiencing in raising funds due to lockdown and  Covid19. I wanted to do something that would take me out of my comfort zone as in my work I am always pushing others to do this.  I was diagnosed with breast cancer at the beginning of this year. At the time I was petrified that I would need chemotherapy and lose my hair.  I was fortunate it had been caught early and only needed a lumpectomy and radiotherapy.  Others are not so fortunate and indeed one of my best friends was also diagnosed with breast cancer this year and is currently undergoing chemotherapy.  Seeing one of your best buddies going through such harsh treatment and losing her hair is hard.  This just made me more keen to do something for charity this year and in particular for cancer research UK. Let's find a cure for this awful disease so that our grandchildren don't have to suffer in the same way.  

Many woman actually choose not to have chemotherapy as they are scared about the hair loss. I do understand why as I was scared and I know my friend was too. Why do we put so much emphasis on our hair? I suppose it is part of us, part of our identity.  Your self-esteem and confidence is built into it.  The media dictates to us that woman will have long flowing locks of hair.  This is what it is to be feminine and to be seen as a woman! Therefore when deciding what to do for my fundraising the most obvious choice to take me out of my comfort zone was to get my 'flowing locks' shaved off, particularly so as my hair has not been cut for over a year now, since I had my diagnosis. My hair is the longest it has ever been since at primary school and once shaved will be the shortest it has ever been since I was born!!!  I really hope you will sponsor me to do this.  I am lucky as this is a choice I have made - others do not get this choice and have other awful side effects to put up with at the same time as losing their hair. I also know that my hair will start to grow back straight away. 

Together we can make cancer a disease of the past :) and feel proud of ourselves as a woman or man with or without hair.

story:
Hello All
My name is Tom McAteer. I started running 4 years ago to improve my physical and mental wellbeing. My first Manchester marathon raised money for Motor Neurone Disease in memory of a friend who died from the illness. I then began running longer distances to see how far I could go. I’m now hooked on endurance running and I’ve made some great friends around the UK.
This might be my last fundraiser. It may also be the longest point-to-point run of my life (215 Miles). I will be starting from my Dad’s birthplace (Kilsyth, North Lanarkshire) and finishing in Preston. I’m going to trace the route travelled by Mum and Dad when they migrated from their birthplace to Preston in the early 1950s.
Alas my Dad, Tommy McAteer, ran out of steam on the 6th November 2020. He was 91 and I miss him very much. Mum died in 2011. Both Mum and Dad consistently encouraged me to be the best I can be. They always supported me to challenge myself. They taught me to know that I can make things happen by believing in myself. Before he died, Dad and I spent time discussing the practicalities of running from Kilsyth to Preston. We laughed when considering the weather, the hills I will encounter … but Dad never discouraged me from giving it a go.
Why Marie Curie? Well, Dad’s active dying process lasted a week. He was in his own home. Much needed respite was given when the District Nurse team organised an overnight stay by a Marie Curie nurse (Amber). The opportunity this gave us as a family to recharge our batteries in our own homes was amazing. Marie Curie rely on donations to help them carry on providing this brilliant service to people with terminal illness and their carers.
I will be posting regular updates to let you know how my preparations are going. I’m looking forward to standing on the start line in March 2021 and remembering my parents on my journey south whilst supporting the fabulous charity Marie Curie.
Thanks for Donating and God bless Running.
Tom

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page!

On Sunday 24th January 2021, we are taking part in the WWF Winter Wander. 2020 has been such a strange year but nature has really helped us to get through it. We'd love to give something back! Our world needs us more than ever before; our Living Planet Report shows a staggering 68% decline in wildlife populations globally. We’re destroying forests, choking oceans with plastic and causing devastating changes to the climate. Globally, we’re using all the planet’s resources faster than nature can restore itself.

Frankie and family xxx
